thread.title: Hearing officer denies lying for state funding
thread.title_full: Albuquerque Journal | Hearing officer denies lying for state funding

author: Colleen Heild / Journal Investigative Reporter
title: Hearing officer denies lying for state funding
text:
SANTA ROSA – A former Jemez Pueblo police chief who now works as a state hearing officer handling appeals of police officer misconduct cases pleaded his own case Wednesday to the New Mexico Law Enforcement Academy Board.
Peter Camacho told the board he didn’t intentionally lie on an application for state law enforcement funding for the Jemez Pueblo department, even though he signed a document attesting that motorists ticketed by his officers weren’t being cited into tribal court when in fact they were.
The board took no action on Camacho’s employment as a hearing officer but the board chairman, Attorney General Hector Balderas, called for an examination of how the state hires hearing officers to “see if there’s any way we can improve the process … and prevent such controversies.”
Camacho’s employment wasn’t on the meeting agenda Wednesday, but he asked to appear at its regular meeting in Santa Rosa.
He told the board that he wasn’t speaking to the board “for vindication or redemption” but wanted to explain “misleading reports by the Albuquerque Journal” involving his signature on an application for state law enforcement funds in February attesting that Jemez Pueblo wasn’t citing non-Indians into tribal court for traffic offenses.
At the time, the pueblo had been doing just that for nearly a year.
In tribal court, defendants aren’t allowed to have lawyers and the proceedings take place behind closed doors. The pueblo keeps court costs and fines, but the citation doesn’t go on a defendant’s driving record.
Camacho, who retired as a lieutenant with the Rio Rancho Police Department, served as Jemez Pueblo police chief for about 18 months until this March.
He currently is presiding over one case but has been assigned no new appeals since the application for law enforcement funding came to light in a Journal news story published in August.
He is one of five hearing officers appointed by the Law Enforcement Academy Board to handle appeals brought by police officers or dispatchers accused of misconduct. He holds formal hearings, listens to testimony and makes recommendations to the board.
Camacho told the board Wednesday he didn’t realize that Jemez Pueblo wouldn’t qualify for money from the state Law Enforcement Protection Fund if officers no longer filed traffic cases in state court.
“I should have read that grant document more carefully,” said Camacho, who told the board there was no personal gain from his action. The pueblo received about $6,000 for equipment and training from the fund based on the 2015-2016 application Camacho signed.
State Police Chief Pete Kassetas, vice chairman of the board, reminded him that the pertinent phrase on the application form was in bold type. A copy of the form obtained by the Journal shows Camacho signed and certified that “no officers of the Tribal or Pueblo police department cite non-Indians into the court of the tribe or pueblo, whether these are civil or criminal citations.”
Kassetas chided Camacho for not informing him about the pueblo’s decision to stop filing traffic cases into state court.
“I was left to find out about that process through the media,” Kassetas said.
Previously, tribal police officers would file traffic cases in state court, but Camacho and pueblo leaders changed the practice in 2014. With the change, the pueblo was projected to collect up to a half million dollars annually in fines from non-Indian motorists.
